awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effects of Monitoring on Immigrant Lives
awd_abstract_narration:
As of 2015, more than 1.8 million immigrants were in removal proceedings, awaiting their turn to appear in immigration courts. However, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) cannot detain all 1.8 million immigrants simultaneously, mostly because ICE's budget only funds 34,000 detention beds on a given day. Therefore, immigrants who do not qualify for mandatory detention are enrolled in the Intensive Supervision Appearance Program (ISAP), which enforces the use of a Global Position System (GPS) ankle monitor. We know that some U.S. immigration policies are associated with immigrant ill health, but scant research exists on how being visually marked and placed under constant surveillance affects physical and mental health as well as health care access. This research will show the impact of the GPS ankle monitoring on the mental and physical health of immigrants.  Project findings will help inform immigration and public health policies. 
 
In the U.S. today, immigrants who do not qualify for mandatory detention are enrolled in Alternative to Detention Programs (ATDP) and must wear a GPS ankle monitor. The project uses ethnographic observations in multiple settings and in-depth, semi-structured interviews with immigrants wearing the GPS ankle monitor. Although these people are no longer in detention, they are still under surveillance via the ankle monitors. The project will document the social, material, mental, and physical effects of the GPS ankle monitors, such as anxiety and difficulty finding housing. This research project makes a theoretical contribution to studies of Latino immigrant populations, while also documenting the effects of surveillance on individuals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Released from detention allows immigrants to gain their freedom, reintegrate into their communities, and enter the labor market, which is true to a certain extent. However, this research shows that when immigrants are released with an electronic monitor, their "freedom" becomes another form of incarceration. Not only does punishment and surveillance are compressed and packaged into these electronic monitors producing uncertainty and anxiety for the immigrant. But also, the electronic monitor acts as a trojan horse that extends the punishment of immigration enforcement and brings surveillance to the families and their community.

This study found that Immigrants monitored to a malfunctioning electronic monitor allow for a punitive relationship between ICE and those monitored electronically. ICE holds immigrants responsible for electronic monitor malfunctions, which are beyond immigrants' control, and then uses those malfunctions to punish immigrants further by extending the time monitored and, in some cases, re-detention.

This study also found that immigrants monitored by this technology are perceived as "criminal aliens." Thus a banishment of the person is reinforced, not only from mainstream society but, most notably, from their ethnic community. The electronic monitor has the power to damage formerly healthy relationships with relatives, friends, and employers. Because the electronic monitor is a beacon of surveillance that attracts ICE and endangers co-ethnics, monitored immigrants are excluded from their community, leading to isolation and social harm.

Finally, the study also found that immigrants shackled to electronic monitors show evidence of mental health harm because of the stigmatized identity produced by this technology. Immigrants shackled to the electronic monitor experience stress, fear, and trauma that ICE will apprehend and deport the wearer or their family.
